active_learning.discussion_prompt: How would you apply this concept in your work environment?
active_learning.peer_teaching: Students pair up; one explains WebSocket handshake security (e.g., Sec-WebSocket-Key validation, origin checks), partner teaches back with a hand-drawn diagram. Switch roles and quiz each other on failure scenarios.
active_learning.problem_solving: Provide sample vulnerable WebSocket code (e.g., Node.js chat app without wss:// or input validation). Students use Burp Suite/browser dev tools to identify/exploit issues (CSWSH, DoS flooding, injection), propose fixes, and simulate a secure deployment in groups.

Prerequisites: HTTP/TLS/CORS. Voter consensus: Full coverage of threats/mitigations, pedagogy emphasis. Use exact flashcard_schema [INSERT flashcard_schema OBJECT]. Output ONLY a JSON array of flashcards, each as: {"id":1, "bloom_level":"Remember", "scaffolding_layer":1, "front":{"question":"...","options":["A)...","B)...","C)...","D)..."]}, "back":{"answer":"B", "explanation":"...","hints":[...],"reference":"..."}}. Ensure distractors follow protocol. Cover all objectives/activities/layers comprehensively, with 50-100 cards balanced by Bloom's (higher for upper levels).
